newsitem.title: SAUDI ARABIA: Saudi launches $253 mln Faisaliah project.
newsitem.headline: Saudi launches $253 mln Faisaliah project.

text.p: Saudi Arabia's King Faisal Foundation laid the cornerstone on Tuesday of a $950 million riyal ($253 million) al-Faisaliah Complex, formally launching what is says is the largest construction project of its kind in the Middle East.

Riyadh's governor Prince Salman laid the cornerstone of the project, a luxury complex which will include a five-star hotel, a shopping mall, office bloc and residential accommodation in the Olaya district in the heart of the capital Riyadh.
"There has never been a commercial multi-use project of this size in the Middle East" Sean Cuddihy, the foundation's director of engineering and construction, told Reuters.
The foundation earlier said it awarded the construction contract to the Saudi Binladen Group which beat a host of foreign and local firms to the deal.
Cuddihy said an agreement would be signed between Binladen and the U.S. Turner Steiner Construction Co to provide project management of the 55,000 square metre site.
"Construction will start immediately and will be completed early in the year 2000," said the foundation, a benevolent organisation based in Riyadh.

The project's financial director Yasser al-Kadi said financing would be provided through a 687 million riyal loan from the Jeddah-based Saudi National Commercial Bank (NCB), the biggest privately-owned bank in the kingdom.
The rest of the project would be covered by the foundation's equity, Kadi said adding that the complex would pay for itself in 10 years.
"The payback period is about 10 years, out of cashflow, not revenue," he said.
The complex will include a 32,000 square metres of office space, 100 residential flats and 26,000 square metres of retail space, Cuddihy said.
The project's sleek 260 metre (850 feet) Al Faisaliah Tower will be the highest building in Saudi Arabia, he added.

The architectural design for the complex was created by Britain's Sir Norman Foster & Partners. Britain's Buro Happold provided the engineering design and is the cost consultant. Both firms in the joint venture will be providing construction management services.
The shopping centre would focus on top class retailers and be unique in Saudi Arabia, Cuddihy said.
"The foundation's intention is to bring in top of the market retailers, especially ones who have not been here before," he said.

He said many Saudi women now tended to go overseas to cities like Paris or New York to shop. "The prince (Foundation secretary-general Prince Bandar bin Saud) wants to make first class retail available in Riyadh,".
No retailers had signed up so far, he said.
"The marketing effort by the foundation is just about to get underway," he added.
Income from al-Faisaliah centre would be used to fund the King Faisal Foundation's philanthropic projects, the foundation said.
The centre would probably not be its last construction project.
"The foundation has the intention of doing further developments in Saudi Arabia," Cuddihy said.
